title: Electromagnetism - flip loop wire magnetic field

content.description:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

In Scenario <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, a rectangular loop of wire with width <math alttext="w" overflow="scroll"><mi>w</mi></math> and length <math alttext="l" overflow="scroll"> <mo>ℓ</mo> </math> is initially inside a region of uniform magnetic field of magnitude <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> directed out of the page, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The loop is then pulled at a constant speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> to the right until it is completely outside the region of the magnetic field. While the loop is being pulled, an <math alttext="e m f" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> <math alttext="open script E sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is induced in the loop.

Scenario <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is identical to Scenario <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> except the loop is rotated <math alttext="90 degrees" overflow="scroll"><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"> <mn>2</mn> </math>. The loop is again pulled at a constant speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> to the right until it is completely outside the region of the magnetic field. While the loop is being pulled in Scenario <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, an <math alttext="e m f" overflow="scroll"> <mi>emf</mi> </math> <math alttext="open script E sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Ɛ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is induced in the loop.
